A SNAP financial strategy with required tools to mobilize and use efficiently the resources in the longterm financing process was developed and finalized by four international consultants on four themes i funding strategy assessment of options for financing PA at national level and at one or two iconic PA ii the financial Needs Assessment and establishment of a financial management system iii Economic valuation of ecosystems and ecosystem services for payments PES and iv sustainable tourism component The main outputs produced are
Review of the current financial situation of Haitis PA national system and
national agency and the current accounting system of the National System of Protected Areas SNAP
Financial Plan of the National System of Protected Areas SNAP and the National Agency for Protected Areas ANAP
Tools on Financing of Protected Areas of Haiti
calculation of Payments for hydrological services provided by protected areas in Haiti
Methodology guideline for economic valuation of protected areas of Haiti
Economic Evaluation of priority protected areas Haiti
Financial tool on sustainable tourism
Solutions for official endorsement and implementation of these strategies are being identified However at date no remarkable progress has been noticed so far
The SNAP project is working towards achievement of this outcome However it will be very difficult to measure the progress made in term of financial sustainability of PA
Network due to the fact UNDPs financial score card is not well adapted to newly established PA network like in Haitis one
Further action is initiated with ANAP to ensure appropriation and ownership of the financial strategy by ANAP and partners

description.narrative: 1 Degree of adoptionenforcement of a National PA System Policy which 1 defines the NPAS and the ANAP 2 clarifies the roles and responsibilities of the Ministries of Environment and Agriculture and their dependencies 3 involves local governments and actors

comment.narrative:
Currently there is no official definition of the NPAS and the ANAP is neither defined nor implemented
The legal and institutional frameworks are not enforced

By year 2 a NPAS policy has been prepared
By Year 3 the policy is approved
By Year 4 the policy is in force

The SNAP project has supported the design and capacity building of ANAP as a legally effective Governmental agency to cope the management of increasing number of protected areas A set of strategic documents involving policy legal frameworks Organic law regulations and guidelines were developed and will be submitted officially to the Government for endorsement and legal approval for SNAP governing management and operation nationwide However there are still some barriers hat need to be lifted by ANAP such as i low or poor fund raising ii
Demarcation of PAs boundaries mapping description etc iii enforcement of regulations access to resources and sanctions etc iv lack of well trained professional and surveillance teams for established PAs v lack of social and economic alternatives for a growing population living in and around PAs
A 5 years Business Plan was developed and finalized as part of the development of the financial strategy The project worked in synergy support PARC project to provide efficient support to MoE in the development of its organic law which is an essential prerequisite for ANAP reinforcement
The promotion of the Organic Law and the strategy organizing the management and sustainable financing mechanisms planned is not yet conducted as the proposed Law framework is not yet adopted
The finalization of the website planned for this year is not yet developed is will being developed and will be likely operational before end of the project As for the Webmaster its creation will start in October 2015
The elaboration and implementation of database on Pas and Biodiversity is on good progress and will be finalized by August 2015
